29.text:
[music]
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain - and this

35.text:
We're at an incredibly professional deerstalking
operation in South Ayrshire.

40.text:
We're talking to you, the good folk of YouTube,
about putting your hunting and shooting successes

45.text:
on film.
There's plenty of Roy Lupton in this week's

49.text:
programme.
He's teaching his peregrine, the Dude, how

52.text:
to hit a new height by flying a kite.
First: Roy's testing a new foxcall from Australia

62.text:
[music]
There are plenty of foxes in Australia and

70.text:
that's all thanks to the expats who were unable
to live Down Under without the thrill of the

76.text:
chase. The Charlies have been there for about
150 years and are well established, and these

81.text:
days so is the noble art of shooting them.
But being on the other side of the world there

86.text:
are cultural and technological differences
in controlling foxes.

90.text:
Scanning the Australian shooting press, like
Guns & Game and Australian Sporting Shooter

95.text:
it all looks pretty familiar. But it's the
way they've recently started calling them,

100.text:
not shooting them, that catches our eye. It
appears that the boys Down Under are winning

105.text:
the arms race on this one.
A few weeks ago a parcel arrived at the Fieldsports

109.text:
Channel headquarters with a DVD, a note, and
a new call called the Silva Fox. They claim

116.text:
amazing results in Australia with this call
and asked it we would we like to try it.

120.text:
Peter Kennedy and the inventor Ron Keihne
have been enjoying Roy's foxshooting exploits

124.text:
on Fieldsports Channel. They suggest he is
the man for the job.

128.text:
I've spent a little bit of time practising
with it and I must say to start with I was

134.text:
struggling a little bit to get any sound out
of this thing at all but now we've finally,

139.text:
finally mastered it after upsetting all the
dogs in the neighbourhood and getting told

144.text:
by the rest of the family to clear out of
the house. And very very impressed with what

149.text:
I've seen so far so I can't wait to take it
out into the field.

151.text:
It looks very good. The instructional DVD
that came with it makes it look a lot easier

158.text:
than it actually is. The first time that I
tried it made it really just sounded like

164.text:
a wet raspberry. As I say, we've got it there
now. And just to show how hard it is to blow

170.text:
what we've decided to do is actually get David
to come and blow it for us. So if you want

174.text:
to come and take my seat, mate, and we'll
see how you do with it.

178.text:
We haven't proved you can blow it yet.
Right so what you got to do - in the mouth

187.text:
- that's it - get the tongue behind it. Hold
it in there.

192.text:
So David's turn to get his chops around the
Silva Fox - he steps up to the plate and delivers

198.text:
some...well, some pathetic school boy raspberries.
Incredible to think he used to play the clarinet.

209.text:
Anyway over to Roy who looks and sounds all
confident, but we know he hit some bum notes

217.text:
You don't do that. I can't do it now.
[music]

234.text:
Playing the Silva Fox is an art, and practice
makes perfect. Ron and Pete have produced

238.text:
an instructional DVD to accompany the call.
Our first impression is that the call is exceptionally

245.text:
loud. It is all very well blowing ear drums
but how does it perform in the field where

249.text:
it really matters. The next day we head off
to some ground to see if the British foxes

254.text:
understand Ozzy.
OK - so we're just on the top of this bank

259.text:
and I am trying to make sure that we've got
a safe backstop if the foxes come. The foxes

263.text:
have been coming out of the side of the wood
here and working along the bottom of this

269.text:
bank just by the side of this lake. So we
can have our first squeak here but what we

274.text:
have got to be careful of is that our wind
is drifting down to the left so we're going

277.text:
to have to keep an eye that nothing crosses
our path and then picks up our wind. And I

279.text:
am hoping that nothing comes from the right
hand side as well because they could just

285.text:
sneak along the other side of the hedgeline
here and just make us through the brambles.

293.text:
I am going to try and squeak reasonably softly
on this first one because I don't want to

300.text:
call any foxes over from that side because
we want to give that a go over there in a

304.text:
minute. So, I am hoping we can just target
these ones. What we can do is give it a go

308.text:
and see.
Roy puts us in a nice position with a great

310.text:
view looking down on to a woodland. He then
unleashes the Silva Fox. If definitely sounds

316.text:
different - raspier, stronger - within seconds
we can hear a magpie and a pheasant getting

321.text:
a bit nervous and out pops a young fox. What
a great start. But he dives back into cover,

328.text:
and we wonder if we have missed our chance.
Roy keeps the call going and after another

334.text:
minute or so the original fox appears with
another in tow. They're probably from the

339.text:
same litter.
The call clearly has them focused on us. They

343.text:
certainly aren't coming in as close as the
Australians have them, but that may be because

347.text:
they are more savvy over here.
Roy takes his chance and drops one, repositions

352.text:
and drops the other.
A great first outing for the Silva Fox - so

356.text:
what does Roy think about the latest addition
to his collection.

359.text:
Excellent. Well, it just goes to show the
old Silva Fox works. I'm really impressed

364.text:
with that.
So it was amazing as well - you could hear

367.text:
the foxes coming all the way through the wood,
so all the magpies were kicking up. And it

371.text:
must have been a good four or five hundred
yards away that the magpies picked them up

374.text:
and they walked all the way through - or worked
themselves all the way through and we got

378.text:
two coming out at the same time there.
So they were working out to us. Came out initially.

384.text:
But the scent unfortunately just wafting a
little bit

387.text:
So they were coming right into us and they
started coming right out into the open towards

390.text:
us.
But then unfortunately the wind just changed

394.text:
a little bit.
And you could see that one just go to turn

397.text:
and run back. So, didnt have the time unfortunately
- or didn't have the opportuntity to call

401.text:
them any closer into shotgun range so we had
to capitalise on what we had. So, took the

405.text:
first shot. And luckily the second cub was
still well within range and got the shot on

413.text:
the second one as well. So, absolutely superb.
The call really does bring them in from a

416.text:
hell of a distance. Very very impressed.
Ron and Pete are looking for a company to

421.text:
distribute the Silva Fox over here in the
UK - but they have sent us 50 for anyone interested

426.text:
in Ozzy rules foxing. Just go to our website,
FieldsportsChannel.tv, and click on our Shop

432.text:
page. For more info about the Silva Fox go
to www.silvafoxwhistles.com and if there is

438.text:
someone in the trade who fancies looking after
these guys and their new invention, please

442.text:
do get in touch with them
Now from Down Under to 'over the top'. It's

447.text:
David on the Fieldsports Britain news stump
[music]

456.text:
This is Fieldsports Britain News.
A huntsman has been praised by police for

461.text:
helping them with a high-speed cross-country
car chase.

464.text:
Zetland Huntsman David Jukes put his hunt-owned
Land Rover at the disposal of the Police in

469.text:
order to catch some criminals. They were
making their getaway across country - but

473.text:
Mr Jukes headed them off and even helped make
an arrest by jumping on a man's back.

478.text:
Need to see in the dark?
The night vision scope that the foxshooters

482.text:
are talking about is now available with a
free external battery pack worth £100 giving

487.text:
20 hours of use per charge. Our friends at
Idleback have the last few of its Pulsar NV550

494.text:
Digital Night Vision Scopes in stock. This
month only, you can buy this exclusively from

500.text:
Idleback with a battery pack priced at just
£1,100. Visit www.idlebackriflechair.co.uk/night-vision

511.text:
to check it out.
Now here's a romantic tale.

514.text:
When two users of the Anglers Afloat kayak
fishing forum, got married, they decided to

519.text:
do it afloat. Guests assembled at Ladram Bay
in South Devon for the union of John and Helen

524.text:
Ingham.
Last weekend, the Inghams and their friends

527.text:
came back to Ladram for a first anniversary
party. It included a kayak fishing competition

532.text:
where the winning team caught nine different
species.

536.text:
And finally a tip of the week - if you don't
tip over.

540.text:
It's a cheap and cheerful way for stalkers
to get their deer airborne to perform a clean

544.text:
gralloch in the field. All you need to do
is bolt a car jack to the back of your quad

549.text:
and Bob's your uncle. Might not work for the
Emperor of Exmoor though.

553.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
news.

558.text:
Stalking the stories, fishing for facts.
[music]

564.text:
Thank you, David.
Buy a comb.

566.text:
Now I've been to South Ayrshire where Chris
Dalton has an enormous amount of land to manage

572.text:
for roe deer.
Chris has a problem that deer managers all

576.text:
over the country will recognise. He wants
to maintain a healthy herd in forestry where

580.text:
- at least for some forestry managers - the
only good deer is a dead deer. The damage

585.text:
these roe deer of South Ayrshire do to forestry
here is all around. Yet the animals are a

591.text:
beautiful sight on an October morning. He
takes me to a piece of woodland to see what's

595.text:
about.
Got driving rain, very cold wind, squally

600.text:
showers. That tends to put the deer under
the trees. I mean, that's where we would be.

604.text:
It's try to get into some shelter, which is
what the deer would do. So we try to go into

608.text:
some fairly thick woodland. Bit of a mixture
of conifer and broadleaf.

611.text:
Unfortunately nothing shootable but I am kind
of surprised we saw anything at all quite

617.text:
frankly this morning.
One of Chris's aims is to bring new people

620.text:
into deerstalking
If they can stalk and work and shoot deer

624.text:
in this environment then they can probably
shoot deer in any environment. So a little

628.text:
bit of a double-edged sword but I think it's
probably a good idea to give people a realistic

636.text:
idea of deer stalking rather than walking
them through a deer park where they think,

639.text:
'Oh well, this is easy'.
Is deerstalking an affordable sport? Chris

642.text:
reckons it's worth every penny
For roebuck stalking, round about £200 a

647.text:
day is where it's going to be. We do the complete
package. I think it seems to work very well.

652.text:
I know when I started stalking what I wanted
was somewhere that's a nice comfortbale base,

656.text:
preferably with facilities, because there's
nothing worse in summer when you;re shooting

659.text:
deer than you've got nowhere to store them,
so we've got the larder and the chiller.

663.text:
If you want to find out more about stalking
with Chris, visit www.ayrstalk.co.uk

670.text:
From traditional stalking to the YouTube generation.
We've been out meeting cameramen for whom

675.text:
hunting and shooting is a passion.
With no real network coverage of fieldsports

680.text:
on the BBC or ITV, many people, ourselves
included, have turned to the internet for

686.text:
entertainment that informs and engages us
with like minded people in the UK and across

691.text:
the world.
We are not alone and here are just some of

695.text:
the enthusiasts using YouTube.
First up it's HuntersVermin. His soft Irish

701.text:
tones talk the viewer through fieldcraft and
the joys of airgunning. We catch up with him

706.text:
at the Midland Game Fair and ask him why he
started uploading films on to the internet.

710.text:
Are you on a bit of a mission to teach people
about your sport? Is that the idea?

718.text:
Teach, entertain, show that not everybody
out there hunting is just worried about putting

726.text:
a pellet in something.
The tools are there. They are very accurate

732.text:
- very useful - and in the right hands they
can put vermin down quickly and cleanly with

738.text:
a single shot, rather than boys shooting at
songbirds. We just don't shoot anything that

743.text:
moves.
We're out there to try and help farmers' protect

749.text:
their crops, to protect livestock in and around
barns and do it sensibly and safely.

755.text:
And you're having fun.
Yes - that's the whole thing. Nobody will

759.text:
stick to it. Nodbody will do that, if they're
not having fun, if they're enjoying themselves

763.text:
I put it on film I put it on YouTube. And
I'nd I;m very surprised how many people actually

768.text:
like it
How many people from all over the world: America,

772.text:
Canade Europe, England, Ireland.
So many people like it - I just can't believe

778.text:
it.
People from around the world saying. ''You're

781.text:
doing a brilliant job.'
People congratulating me - 'I've learnt so

785.text:
much from watching the videos on YouTube and
that.'

788.text:
I'm overwhelmed with how well people have
taken it.

791.text:
Another of our online friends is the Ghostmaker
aka Malc Barnard. Malc is always looking to

798.text:
push the boundaries with technology - designing
kit and adapting cameras to get the best shots.

803.text:
We grab a chat with him at the Bisley Live
shooting show.

805.text:
You're not just Malc Barnard - the bloke with
the camera over you shoulder at game fairs

809.text:
- you are Ghostmaker.
Yeah - Ghostmaker1970 - that's how it all

813.text:
started off.
So what's the point for you of putting your

818.text:
hunting/shooting on YouTube
A sense of community, giving a little bit

824.text:
back. I do like try and help other shooters
out. When I used to go to the local ranges

830.text:
and stuff, I used to spend most of my time
with new shooters trying to help them over

836.text:
the pitfalls that there are and just trying
to generally help people out so that's why

842.text:
I started Ghostmaker1970.
What kind of stuff do they want to see on

847.text:
your channel?
Tutorial videos are quite popular. Product

851.text:
reviews and that sort of thing are quite popular.
We're actually doing a night vision series

856.text:
at the moment which has stirred the juices
with quite a few of the viewers. I think that

861.text:
sort of thing is quite key to keeping people's
interest going.

867.text:
Are you going to replace the Shooting Times
do you reckon?

872.text:
Maybe not this year.
Ian Summerell and James Marchington are among

876.text:
the Cecil B De Milles who have found an outlet
on the world wide web.

880.text:
Ian is one of the voices of the Union of Country
Sports Workers.

884.text:
James is a well-known magazine editor who
offers practical tips and simply stuff he

888.text:
likes the look of.
Organisations such as the Countryside Alliance

892.text:
use YouTube to get their message out to a
wide range of viewers, from films with major

896.text:
league TV celebrities to informational videos
about rural issues which are shown to politicians

902.text:
at party conferences. Fieldsports Channel
runs the Countryside Alliance film unit and

906.text:
makes all these films for the CA.
GunsOnPegs.com is another organisation which

912.text:
uses YouTube. The free website for shooters
to find shoots runs films about its estates

917.text:
from all over the UK. You can watch these
on YouTube or on GunsOnPegs.com's own website.

925.text:
If you are watching this on YouTube, you will
see links to all these YouTube sites appearing

929.text:
on the screen. You can click on them to find
out more.

932.text:
Here is another passionate bunch of guys,
uploading tips and techniques. Based in Southern

937.text:
Ireland, they are well known across the world.
We meet them at the Birr Castle Game Fair.

942.text:
So we're getting a lot of contacts from around
the world now because of the YouTube channel.

947.text:
It's going very well.
What sort of things have you got on it?

950.text:
We've got pigeon shooting and decoying. That's
a great treat.

954.text:
We're shooting on oilseed rape during the
winter.

958.text:
It's more of a watch-and-learn.We're giving
out good ideas, especially on the game crops,

962.text:
game releasing. We've a game release programme
going now with open top pheasant pens and

967.text:
the game crop planting and growing. So we're
just doing demonstrations showing bringing

971.text:
them down on days out.
YouTube is fairly easy to use. I found it

975.text:
easy. I had no knowledge when I started. So
I was able to do it.

980.text:
Now, let's go fly a kite. Well that's exactly
what Roy Lupton's done to train his peregrine,

986.text:
the Dude.
We know Roy enjoys playing with big boys'

990.text:
toys but with his latest bit of kit he really
is taking the Mick. We are going to fly a

995.text:
kite - no not a red one but a yellow and blue
one - and the reason is we are training his

999.text:
young peregrine, the Dude, to increase his
pitch and his strength.

1004.text:
Training falcons with kites started in the
USA.With their vast open plains some of their

1009.text:
birds are now achieving heights of 2,000ft.
Roy is looking for about 1,000ft from the

1014.text:
Dude eventually and today it'll be more like
500.

1018.text:
Many years ago I used to do a lot of kite
training. And I found myself going back to

1023.text:
playing with balls of string and big toys.
And basically what we do is we put the kite

1030.text:
up on a line, and we dangle the lure from
the line which is on a detachable mechanism

1038.text:
so when the bird goes up to it, the lure detaches
and it follows back down or the lure comes

1043.text:
back down the string with the falcon attached.
And basically what we're trying to is just

1047.text:
- 1- build fitness in the falcon because it;s
quite hard work for him to go up to it and

1052.text:
- 2 - we're trying to encourage him that height
is a good thing above us. So then what we

1057.text:
do, once he realises that he can go up and
he's got the strength to make a good height

1061.text:
above us, then we start going out and we start
trying to find game for him to fly on, so

1066.text:
we will get him up and then we will start
looking for coveys of partridges to flush

1070.text:
underneath him.
Pete takes the kite to the top of the hill.

1073.text:
We're a bit nervous because the wind is much
stronger up there. We could risk losing the

1077.text:
kite.
Before the kite is released Roy attaches the

1081.text:
lure.
What we've got here is a clip that fits on

1083.text:
to the main line. So that should run back
down towards us. It runs quite freely. And

1088.text:
we've go a little rig here that attaches on
with a pressure release clip.

1094.text:
So it just attaches on to the main ring underneath
the kite.

1100.text:
And what we're hoping will happen is that
as the falcon takes the lure it pulls down

1104.text:
on here and just the clip off allowing the
lure and the falcon to come down the line

1112.text:
back towards us.
Three, two, one, go.

1117.text:
With the kite airborne the Dude is brought
out for his exercise.

1120.text:
So what we're going to do now is just go back
a little bit just so as he can see the kite

1125.text:
up there. And you'll notice, hopefully, if
he's going to do what he should do, as I take

1131.text:
the hood off, he'll just look around a little
bit, look up to the kite, realise the lure's

1135.text:
there, and hopefully he'll be off and starting
to mount on his way up there.

1139.text:
So, as long as no pigeon flushes as he's on
his way, we should be all right.

1148.text:
The Dude makes good progress and reaches the
kite in less than a minute.

1152.text:
He attacks the lure once, twice, and then
gets a good grip and descends with his prize.

1158.text:
So how does Roy rate his performance?
Yeah - that was OK - he did well on that - he

1163.text:
mounted quite nicely, so we'll just ask him
to step off of the lure, so he gets the rest

1167.text:
of of his grub. And a nice successful training
session for the afternoon.

1174.text:
So, that tired you out a little bit. Not too
bad, though. I thought he was going to be

1179.text:
panting a lot more after working himself like
that but he did well.

1184.text:
Hopefully another week and he'll be up to
1,000ft and then we can startintroducing him

1189.text:
to game, so that's when it really gets fun..
With the Dude's training over, it's time for

1193.text:
a few quick training flights with Pete's golden
eagle, Merlin.

1197.text:
The fox lure is dragged behind the 4x4 and
Merlin pumps after his quarry.

1210.text:
After a couple of successful runs the peregrine,
the golden eagle and the kite are all packed

1214.text:
away for another day's fun.
We're back next week. And in the meantime

1219.text:
you can buy that Silva Fox fox call on our
website, www.fieldsportschannel.tv until it

1227.text:
finds a UK distributor. And while you're on
the website, why not click to like us on Facebook,

1233.text:
or follow us on Twitter or pop your email
address into our ConstantContact email subscription

1238.text:
form, and that way we can tell you all about
our programme every week.
